awd_titl_txt: Mechanisms of chemosensory behavioral plasticity in C. elegans
awd_abstract_narration:
All animals sense and respond to multiple chemicals in their environment. Chemical cues signal the presence of food, mates, predators, and toxic substances, and animals are attracted, repelled, or indifferent to individual odors. However, the responses of animals to chemicals are not fixed, but can be altered by their past experience and current state. For example, prolonged prior exposure to an odor decreases subsequent responses to that chemical, and juveniles and adults can exhibit different responses to chemicals. This flexibility ensures that the animal exhibits the behavior that is most appropriate for its current condition. The overall goal of this project is to explore how an animal's experience and its developmental stage alter the functions of the nervous system to drive different chemical-sensing behaviors. Given the importance of smell and taste in animal lifecycles, this work allows us to begin to explore how changes in the environment may impact animal welfare, and aid in animal husbandry and conservation efforts. The proposed work supports the training of high school, undergraduate and graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows, and all efforts will be made to involve members of underrepresented minority groups. The project also builds research relationships between university labs and high school students and teachers. The insights from this work are shared with the public via hands-on demonstrations at local science museums and science fairs. The proposed work also incorporates collaborations among biologists, chemists and bioengineers, and is thus expected to promote interdisciplinary learning and innovation.

Both innate and learned behaviors are flexible, and are extensively modulated by an animal's experience as well as its external and internal state. The specific goal of this proposal is to identify and characterize the molecules, neurons, and circuits that mediate context- and developmental stage-specific plasticity in chemosensory behavioral responses of the nematode C. elegans. Preliminary experiments suggest that contextual cues modulate the output of antagonistic neural circuits to toggle the response to a simple alcohol between attraction and aversion. The behavioral strategies and neuronal mechanisms underlying this response flexibility is characterized using high-resolution analyses of behavioral states and neuronal activity under defined conditions. C. elegans chemosensory behaviors are also dramatically modulated as a function of developmental stage and environmental experience. The proposed research characterizes this experience- and stage-dependent chemosensory behavioral plasticity, and identifies the required neuronal and molecular mechanisms. Results from this work provide new information about the mechanisms by which animals efficiently alter their behaviors in response to changing external and internal conditions.

por.por_cntn:
Animals are able to detect and respond to chemical signals in their environment in order to identify prey, potential mates, and predators. In order to exhibit the most optimal behavior, these chemical-sensing behaviors must not only be robust and sensitive, but must also be highly flexible such that the animal?s response to a specific chemical is changed based on its experience, internal state and current conditions. The inability to reshape chemical-sensing behaviors appropriately has significantly deleterious consequences on animal fitness and survival. The overall scientific goals of this project were two-fold: to identify and describe how the behavior of an adult animal is influenced by a) conditions experienced during development, and b) its immediate context. Both goals have been completed.

In the first, we have now found that early experiences profoundly influence the chemical-sensing behaviors of adult animals. Depending on environmental conditions, the nematode C. elegans chooses one of two alternative developmental pathways to adulthood. We found that adult animals exhibit markedly different responses to food-related chemicals based on the developmental pathway selected. We showed that these different chemical response behaviors are likely driven by changes in the levels of specific chemical receptor proteins present in single sensory neurons, and identified molecules that alter receptor protein levels. Our findings suggest that early experience changes the expression of specific genes in chemical-sensing neurons to alter chemical-seeking behaviors in adult animals.

In the second, we have shown that the response to specific food-related chemicals switches from attraction to avoidance based on the presence or absence of other related chemicals in the environment. Specifically, we found that this switch in the behavior occurs due to the chemicals either silencing or activating a single chemical-sensing neuron depending on the context of the animal. We identified some of the molecules that are required for this switch and propose that this behavioral flexibility allows the animal to accurately assess its chemical environment and make the most appropriate behavioral decision. In related projects, we also described a new pathway by which bacteria present in the gut targets the host's nervous system to alter its chemosensory behaviors, and identified a new pathway by which signals from the gut affect how the animal responds to its environment.

This project supported the training of undegraduates, graduate students, postdoctoral fellows and research associates, including scientists from communities underrepresentd in the sciences. The project also supported extensive collaborations across multiple institutions. As part of this work, biology PhD students and postdocs were also trained in principles of microfabrication. All project participants presented their work at public forums. The PI participated extensively in outreach activities (limited in the last two years due to the pandemic) including participating in the local SACNAS chapter meeting, presenting at a local school, presenting at online forums, and participating in virtual activities at the Discovery Museum (Acton) as a fellow of the Portal to the Public Program. She also disseminated findings from this work in invited presentations at universities and conferences (virtual and in-person).
